channel.title: Random numbers
channel.description: is there a way to get all the numbers (5 in total on to a list?) starting with 4 like 48283 42823 49999 (all starting with 4) how do you get all of them on to one list (its going to be a million or more but I don't care)

item.title: Random numbers
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I come more from the angle that a veteran Java programmer will make novice mistakes when working with direct memory in a low-level language. It’s rather unfortunate, too, seeing as being able to understand how the operating system and memory work is paramount to being a good computer scientist. Those are often left out or heavily hidden from Java (and other managed languages) programmers.

I would recommend learning C before C++, seeing as C++ is derived from it. Bad practices coming from learning from bad programmers. You can learn bad practices when learning any language; C and C++ are no exception (and may even be the prime example).

Read full topic

item.title: Random numbers
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:65, topic:533919”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=652716.msg4376802#msg4376802 date=1382290169]
And really, saying you have a Java certification qualifies you of little in my book. I’ve seen and done some of those certification tests, they really are not worth bragging about, sorry. I commend you for taking your Java education to the next level, but Java is not a particularly difficult language. If anything, achieving that certification means you should be moving onto more difficult languages and trying to master them now. You would be amazed at how much better of a Java programmer you would become if you try to apply concepts learned from other languages to it.
[/quote]
I’ve been working on C++ – it’s basically identical in terms of concepts to Java, though there are a few advantages. Thanks though.[/quote]

stop posting

[quote=“Taharok, post:66, topic:533919”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=652716.msg4376806#msg4376806 date=1382290519]

And really, saying you have a Java certification qualifies you of little in my book. I’ve seen and done some of those certification tests, they really are not worth bragging about, sorry. I commend you for taking your Java education to the next level, but Java is not a particularly difficult language. If anything, achieving that certification means you should be moving onto more difficult languages and trying to master them now. You would be amazed at how much better of a Java programmer you would become if you try to apply concepts learned from other languages to it.

I’ve been working on C++ – it’s basically identical in terms of concepts to Java, though there are a few advantages. Thanks though.
[/quote]

It’s nothing close to Java. There mere differences between C++ and Java is a featureset larger than the entire Java language. But very good that you are learning it. I would recommend you learn C, as well. It’s much easier to learn C++ if you know C, and C++ is an extremely large and complicated language.

Another problem is Java programmers often suck at memory management, so starting with easier memory management in C is preferred before moving onto complex concepts like allocators, smart pointers, reference counting, implementing your own GC, etc.[/quote]

although you need to be aware that learning C and C++ concurrently can result in headaches and bad practices. heh…

i wouldn’t say that Java programmers suck at memory management insomuch as they simply aren’t exposed to it unless they’re lucky unlucky and, along the line, encounter something from the (fortunately quite small) set of memory problems. unless you’re saying that Java programmers tend to suck at mem management in C/C++, idk, i’ve found a lot of C/C++ newbies tend to overemphasize the memory management (free(a); free(a); lol) and fall-short elsewhere.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:65, topic:533919”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=652716.msg4376802#msg4376802 date=1382290169]
And really, saying you have a Java certification qualifies you of little in my book. I’ve seen and done some of those certification tests, they really are not worth bragging about, sorry. I commend you for taking your Java education to the next level, but Java is not a particularly difficult language. If anything, achieving that certification means you should be moving onto more difficult languages and trying to master them now. You would be amazed at how much better of a Java programmer you would become if you try to apply concepts learned from other languages to it.
[/quote]
I’ve been working on C++ – it’s basically identical in terms of concepts to Java, though there are a few advantages. Thanks though.[/quote]

It’s nothing close to Java. There mere differences between C++ and Java is a featureset larger than the entire Java language. But very good that you are learning it. I would recommend you learn C, as well. It’s much easier to learn C++ if you know C, and C++ is an extremely large and complicated language.

Another problem is Java programmers often suck at memory management, so starting with easier memory management in C is preferred before moving onto complex concepts like allocators, smart pointers, reference counting, implementing your own GC, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Random numbers
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/ThePerilsofJavaSchools.html

That’s a good one to read for any aspiring Java experts.

Honestly, all I have to comment about all these solutions is: try doing it in C, then port it over to Java. If you use a lot of low-level programming, you reach a point where you start to really appreciate the easy concatenation or string ops that Java has–so much so that you learn how to not depend on them. In C, you are forced to do things in a more direct way without using tons of memory allocations, etc.

And really, saying you have a Java certification qualifies you of little in my book. I’ve seen and done some of those certification tests, they really are not worth bragging about, sorry. I commend you for taking your Java education to the next level, but Java is not a particularly difficult language. If anything, achieving that certification means you should be moving onto more difficult languages and trying to master them now. You would be amazed at how much better of a Java programmer you would become if you try to apply concepts learned from other languages to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Random numbers
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:60, topic:533919”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=652716.msg4375535#msg4375535 date=1381955136]
I don’t think there is a problem unless you are actually using a String. I’m using the integer conversion from the string class. So, really, I’m using a integer in String format instead of using String j = “”+i;
[/quote]Those are the same thing :o[/quote]
Graaaahh! You all have me bugged. I can’t find another solution.
BAM! Suck it, I got it

public static int[] random(int amt) { int[] array = new int[amt]; for (int i = 0; i < amt; i++) { int random = 40000 + new Random().nextInt(10000); array[i] = random; } return array; }

I think he wanted 5-digit numbers that started with the number 4

Read full topic

item.title: Random numbers
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:55, topic:533919”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=652716.msg4375517#msg4375517 date=1381953524]
I seriously think this is what you are wanting.

random(4, 5) should give you exactly what you’re asking.

public int[] random(String startValue, int amt) { int[] array = new int[amt]; int random = new Random().nextInt(); for (int i = 0; i < amt;) { if (String.valueOf(random).startsWith(startValue)) { array[i] = random; i++; } } return array; }
[/quote]We just had a whole conversation about why using strings for this was bad :[/quote]

Well, I stayed outta the argument. I guess since it’s bad I might as well read through it

Read full topic

[quote=“xxxtilllyxxx, post:5, topic:533919”]^ I think he wants to know if he can imprint those numbers generated randomly, instead of sequentially.

E.g, your’s imprints, 40000, 40001, 40002 up till 49999.

His would do something like, 40958, 49638, 46542, 45488 etc., each number getting ‘ticked’ off, until all possible outcomes from 40000 - 49999 are done.[/quote]If thats what he wants he can use the min-max method arham posted in the coordspammer snippet i made, and save the ones that have already appeared in an array, and check if they’re in there

item.title: Random numbers
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Davidi2:

If he worked off your example he would be learning bad practices, simple as that. It gives no valid insight into solving the question properly. I couldn’t give less shits about you or you thinking you’re helping, but it is his problem if he uses ANY of your code (so you can cut the ‘work off of’ bullshit, there is no good code in your solution, even your for loop is incorrectly done) and learns bad practices from it, because nothing you posted at all is good java practice. And that’s why I pointed it out, because I like to help people learn proper practice.

Ironically you just said you didn’t help provide insight into any fixes, only ridiculed the code. You know what that makes you? By definition, ignorant. That’s not a predetermined quality, you can fix that you know.
